title: Heart Rate Variability (HRV): What's Normal – and How to Increase It
content:
Heart Rate Variability (HRV): What's Normal – and How to Increase It

Article by James Stables | Published June 18, 2025

What is HRV?

Heart rate variability measures the tiny differences in time between each heartbeat, in milliseconds. Even at a steady heart rate of 60 beats per minute, intervals between beats vary slightly—one gap might be 1.0 seconds, the next 1.1 seconds. This variability reflects how well your autonomic nervous system adapts to stress.

The Science Behind HRV

The autonomic nervous system controls involuntary processes through the sinoatrial node (the heart's natural pacemaker). Two opposing branches create HRV dynamics:

The sympathetic nervous system drives the "fight-or-flight" response.

The parasympathetic nervous system promotes "rest and digest" via the vagus nerve.

Heart rate variability (HRV) reflects the constant push–pull between these two systems.

What's Normal?

HRV is highly individual. General age-based benchmarks include:

Mid-twenties: 55–105 average range

Sixties-seventies: 25–45 average range

Males typically show slightly higher HRV than females.

Factors Affecting HRV

Low HRV can result from illness, stress, overtraining, menstrual cycle phases, alcohol, dehydration, heat, or chronic disease. Research shows drinking alcohol can lower HRV by approximately 22 milliseconds the following day.

Improvement Strategies

Quality sleep and wind-down routines

Cold exposure to stimulate the vagus nerve

Mindfulness practices (5-minute sessions showed benefits)

Resonant breathing at 5 breaths per minute

The article emphasizes tracking HRV over extended periods for meaningful health insights rather than relying on single measurements.
